channel.title: NYT > World
channel.copyright: Copyright 2013 The New York Times Company

item.title: Sinosphere Blog: Q. and A.: Detective Novelist Qiu Xiaolong on Chinese Corruption
item.description: The creator of Inspector Chen discusses political corruption, censorship, longing for good Chinese food in St. Louis and Bo Xilai not returning his table tennis paddle.
item.dc:creator: By EDWARD WONG
item.media:credit: Dilip Vishwanat for The New York Times
item.media:description: Qiu Xiaolong's novels often explore the corruption that has sprung up amid China's one-party authoritarian rule.

item.title: Security Council Authorizes More Peacekeeping Troops for South Sudan
item.description: The United Nations Security Council voted to nearly double its peacekeeping force in South Sudan, hoping that a rapid influx of international forces would help quell the violence.
item.dc:creator: By NICHOLAS KULISH and RICK GLADSTONE
item.media:description: A displaced family from South Sudan's Nuer tribe, who fled their home amid ethnic violence, built a makeshift shelter inside the United Nations Mission in Sudan facility Monday on the outskirts of capital Juba.

item.title: $40 Million in Aid Set for Bangladesh Garment Workers
item.description: The fund for the Rana Plaza factory building collapse is considered a landmark in compensating families of garment industry victims, in terms of both the amount to be paid and the sophistication of the arrangements.
item.dc:creator: By STEVEN GREENHOUSE
item.media:credit: Tomas Munita for The New York Times
item.media:description: The Rana Plaza ruins, where over 1,100 died.

item.title: Musharraf Trial Postponed After Discovery of Unassembled Bomb
item.description: A three-member special court is trying the former military ruler on charges that he subverted the Constitution when he imposed emergency rule in 2007.
item.dc:creator: By SALMAN MASOOD

item.title: The Lede: NASA Astronauts Make Christmas Eve Spacewalk to Repair International Space Station
item.description: NASA’s astronauts stepped outside the International Space Station on Christmas Eve to complete repairs to the cooling station.
item.dc:creator: By JENNIFER PRESTON

item.title: Nepal’s Maoists Agree to Join Constituent Assembly
item.description: The Maoists, who suffered a stinging defeat in November elections and filed claims of fraud, agreed to delay an inquiry they are seeking as the assembly is formed.
item.dc:creator: By GARDINER HARRIS

item.title: Deadly Cross-Border Attacks on Gaza-Israel Border
item.description: The deaths of an Israeli laborer and a Palestinian toddler were the latest in a growing wave of Israeli-Palestinian violence.
item.dc:creator: By ISABEL KERSHNER
item.media:description: Israeli army paramedics treated a civilian shot near the Israeli border with Gaza on Tuesday.

item.title: Bulgaria’s Struggle Belies Promise of E.U. Membership
item.description: Seven years since joining the European bloc, protests continue for clean government and economic growth, pointing to the prolonged process of change.
item.dc:creator: By ANDREW HIGGINS

item.title: Russian Amnesty Now Includes Greenpeace Case
item.description: The authorities gave amnesty to one crew member of the Greenpeace ship seized three months ago, signaling that the same is planned for the others.
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations
item.dc:creator: By ANDREW E. KRAMER

item.title: Bomb Rips Through Egyptian Police Building
item.description: At least 15 people were killed in the bombing in the city of Mansoura, the deadliest such attack since the July ouster of Mohamed Morsi as president.
item.dc:creator: By KAREEM FAHIM and MAYY EL SHEIKH
item.media:description: Men inspected the destruction in the Egyptian city of Mansura on Tuesday after a powerful car bomb.

item.title: The Lede: NASA’s Tweets and Video of Emergency Spacewalk
item.description: Video and Twitter updates from NASA of astronauts fixing a cooling pump on the exterior of the International Space Station.
item.dc:creator: By JENNIFER PRESTON

item.title: India Ink: Image of the Day: December 24
item.description: Indian army officials at the Wagah border post after returning from Pakistan.
item.dc:creator: By THE NEW YORK TIMES

item.title: Edwin A. Shuman III, Former Prisoner of War Who Defied Hanoi Hilton Guards, Dies at 82
item.description: Commander Shuman, a Navy pilot whose plane was shot down in 1968, led an effort by prisoners to conduct church services in the North Vietnamese camp known as the Hanoi Hilton.
item.dc:creator: By RICHARD GOLDSTEIN
item.media:description: Lt. Cmdr. Edwin A. Shuman III

item.title: Report Faults Increase in China’s Local Government Debt
item.description: The report by the Chinese Academy of Social Sciences is the latest indication that China may be investing too aggressively in property and infrastructure projects.
item.dc:creator: By DAVID BARBOZA

item.title: India Ink: A Tribute to the Uncrowned Travancore King
item.description: Uthradom Thirunal Marthanda Varma, who died Dec. 16 at the age of 91, was beloved by Keralites for his humility and devotion to the Sri Padmanabhaswamy temple.
item.dc:creator: By T.P. SREENIVASAN
item.media:credit: Sanjit Das for The New York Times
item.media:description: Uthradom Thirunal Marthanda Varma in Thiruvananthapuram, Kerala, on July 5, 2011.

item.title: Lens Blog: Rooms for Rescued Dogs in Malaysia
item.description: A German woman moved to Penang, Malaysia, hoping for tranquility in her retirement, but before long she was running a shelter for about 250 stray dogs.
item.dc:creator: By KERRI MACDONALD

item.title: Experts Say North Korea May Be Producing Fuel for Nuclear Reactor
item.description: The U.S.-Korea Institute, citing analysis of satellite images, said Tuesday that a building retooled to produce fresh fuel rods appeared to be operational.
item.dc:creator: By CHOE SANG-HUN

item.title: Powerful Bombing at Egypt Police Station Kills 12
item.description: A powerful explosion believed to be caused by a car bomb ripped through a police headquarters north of Cairo on Tuesday, killing 12 people and wounding more than 100.
item.dc:creator: By THE ASSOCIATED PRESS

item.title: Sinosphere Blog: In China, Dreaming of a Less Smoggy Christmas
item.description: Though Christmas Eve was an ordinary working day for most Chinese, there was plenty of irritation about the heavy air pollution that hit at least 78 cities.
item.dc:creator: By DIDI KIRSTEN TATLOW
item.media:description: Residents covering their faces amid haze this month in Zhengzhou in Henan Province.

item.title: Alan Turing, Enigma Code-Breaker and Computer Pioneer, Wins Royal Pardon
item.description: Alan Turing, a British mathematician, was convicted on charges of homosexuality in 1952; he committed suicide two years later at the age of 41.
item.dc:creator: By EMMA G. FITZSIMMONS
item.media:credit: Sherborne School, via Agence France-Presse — Getty Images

item.title: Egypt Car Bombing Targets Police
item.description: The explosion killed at least 14 people and injured nearly 100, according to the state news agency and a security official.
item.dc:creator: By THE ASSOCIATED PRESS

item.title: Surprising British Recovery Prompts Diverse Views on Causes and Prospects
item.description: Explaining what prompted Britain’s recovery amounts to an economic policy Rorschach test: are the austerity policies choking Europe’s growth or fostering it?
item.dc:creator: By DANNY HAKIM
item.media:description: George Osborne, chancellor of the Exchequer, left, hailed the recent economic upturn in Britain as evidence that his austerity policies were working, and promised more of the same.

item.title: World Briefing | Africa: Libya: Political Transition Extended
item.description: Libya’s interim Parliament voted to extend the country’s postrevolutionary transition, giving itself an extra year to oversee the writing of a constitution and the holding of elections, members said.
item.dc:creator: By THE ASSOCIATED PRESS

item.title: World Briefing | Middle East: Israel: Palestinian Hunger Striker Freed
item.description: The Palestinian, Samer Issawi, had taken only water and infusions from Aug. 1, 2012, until April 23 of this year, becoming a symbol of the Palestinian struggle against Israel
item.dc:creator: By THE ASSOCIATED PRESS

item.title: Sinosphere Blog: Are You Qualified to Be a Journalist in China? Take the Test
item.description: Chinese reporters are studying hundreds of pages of materials on Chinese-style journalism in order to pass a test early next year to renew their official press cards.
item.dc:creator: By MIA LI and BREE FENG
item.media:description: A policeman stands guard outside the Southern Weekly newspaper in Guangzhou last January after reporters went on strike over a scrapped New Year's editorial. Next year, reporters will have to pass a new exam to keep their press cards.
